Award.AwardTitle: CRII: CPS: Provably-safe Interventions for Human-Cyber-Physical Systems (HCPS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Human interaction with the physical world is increasingly mediated by autonomy, as planes assist pilots, robots assist surgeons, and cars assist drivers. Automation is introduced in such systems to aid humans and guarantee safety and performance. However, such guarantees are hard to provide, since humans may misunderstand the automation's intentions or behave in an unanticipated manner; tragic examples like the crash of Air France flight 447 illustrate that such confusion between pilots and autopilots can lead to catastrophic outcomes. Although some applications may someday yield to full automation (e.g., cars can already drive themselves in traffic), legal and ethical concerns related to safety, accountability, and non-repudiation will ensure humans and autonomy must be capable of handing off control authority at multiple levels in many such systems for the foreseeable future. The principal investigator (PI) proposes to flexibly deploy degrees of autonomy in the presence of human collaborators to compensate for changes in task or environmental conditions. Though PI focuses on robotic teleoperation for concreteness, the anticipated results will lead to general principles that benefit a variety of CPS with humans in-the-loop.

Providing safety and performance guarantees for any system involving humans is a lofty goal. PI proposes to achieve this goal by (i) targeting our effort on applications in robotic teleoperation and (ii) integrating findings from multiple established academic disciplines, including engineering disciplines like human factors and control theory that consider the interaction between people and dynamic physical processes, as well as scientific disciplines like neuromechanical motor control and behavioral game theory that account for how humans interact individually and in groups. The proposed work paves the way for provably-safe teleoperated robots distributed in an urban area to provide services in transportation, manufacturing, telemedicine, and emergency response by developing principles for predictive modeling and automated interventions. Unlike the present day, where incompatibilities in aims or means for humans and autonomy lead to performance degradation ranging from significant to catastrophic, the proposed work envisions a future wherein humans can be safely deployed amidst cyber-physical systems in society with high confidence.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As human interaction with the physical world is increasingly mediated by intelligent machines that learn from and adapt to their human partners, it is increasingly important to establish rigorous techniques for guaranteeing performance of the resulting human-cyber-physical system.  Performance is not automatically guaranteed, as humans can be confused by complex interfaces or utilize machines in unforeseen ways.  This project created theoretical and experimental knowledge regarding how humans learn to control dynamic intelligent machines like teleoperated robots.  This knowledge provided new techniques for design and analysis of high-performance interaction between humans and cyber-physical systems.  Future work could extend and apply these results to applications in manufacturing, healthcare, transportation, emergency response, and disaster relief.


The results of this project draw upon and contribute to a body of knowledge regarding how humans learn to control complex systems that spans multiple disciplines including neuroengineering, behavioral economics, and human-robot interaction.  As one example of potential interdisciplinary impact, one of the project's graduate student researchers has leveraged findings and techniques from this project to diagnose motor planning deficits in children with cerebral palsy.  This creative proposal shows the potential for research in human-cyber-physical systems to impact scientific or clinical research.


This project involved trainees with diverse disciplinary backgrounds working in a vertical mentoring structure wherein doctoral and post-doctoral researchers collaborated with and mentored one another as well as undergraduate and high school students.  Most importantly, students from groups that are traditionally underrepresented in STEM fields were recruited and trained at the high school, undergraduate, and graduate levels to conduct cutting-edge engineering research on cyber-physical systems.


This project helped to establish an ongoing collaborative interaction between PI Burden and a highly-interdisciplinary group headquartered in the UW Law School focused on technology policy.  This group has published influential reports on the deployment of (semi-)autonomous vehicles and chronic neurotechnologies.  We are actively working to translate results from this project to inform policy related to dynamic interaction between humans and machines, i.e. human-cyber-physical systems, such as teleoperated robots used in manufacturing, healthcare, transportation, emergency response, and disaster relief.  In particular, we envision the techniques developed on this project for guaranteeing the performance of closed-loop interactions between humans and cyber-physical systems may enable these technologies to be deployed in society with high confidence.
